Is there a way to plot the data "under" the axes?
I have a polar heatmap and I'd like to be able to see the radial coords.
MWE
```using Plots

messages.text: Is there a way to specify the colorbar ticks? For example, if I am plotting angle data from -180 to 180 degrees, I can set `clims=(-180, 180)`, but the ticks on the colorbar are drawn from -150 to 150 in 50degree increments.  Ideally I'd like something like this, but various combinations of `zticks` or `cticks` etc haven't worked.  ``` heatmap(360*rand(8, 10).-180, clims=(-180, 180), zticks=collect(-180:45:180)) ```

messages.text: Hi all, I'm wondering if there's a way to change the default plotting options at the beginning of a section? I have a lot of plots with repeated options, like the following:  plot(10 .^(LinRange(-2,1,100)), x -> exp(x), color = :black, lw=2,         xlabel = "x",          ylabel = L"$\exp\ (x)$",          xaxis = :log10,          yaxis = :log10,          legend = false,          size = (400,400),          framestyle=:box,          xticks=([0.01, 0.1, 1, 10, 100], [0.01, 0.1, 1, 10, 100]),          minorticks=10,         tickfont = font(12, "serif-roman"),          fontfamily = "serif-roman",          guidefontsize = 14,          grid=false)  Setting default values for 'size', 'fontfamily', 'grid', 'legend', 'framestyle', etc., at the start of a Jupyter notebook would be quite useful. Thanks!

text.text:
Hi all, I'm wondering if there's a way to change the default plotting options at the beginning of a section? I have a lot of plots with repeated options, like the following:

plot(10 .^(LinRange(-2,1,100)), x -> exp(x), color = :black, lw=2,
        xlabel = "x", 
        ylabel = L"$\exp\ (x)$", 
        xaxis = :log10, 
        yaxis = :log10, 
        legend = false, 
        size = (400,400), 
        framestyle=:box, 
        xticks=([0.01, 0.1, 1, 10, 100], [0.01, 0.1, 1, 10, 100]), 
        minorticks=10,
        tickfont = font(12, "serif-roman"), 
        fontfamily = "serif-roman", 
        guidefontsize = 14, 
        grid=false)

Setting default values for 'size', 'fontfamily', 'grid', 'legend', 'framestyle', etc., at the start of a Jupyter notebook would be quite useful. Thanks!
